title: unchecked unserialize usages in audit-trail-extension/audit-trail-extension.php

profile.name: Ian Dunn
profile.about: I'm a WordPress developer who maintains several small open source projects.

vulnerability_information:
in:
	https://github.com/iandunn/audit-trail-extension/blob/master/audit-trail-extension.php#L106
	https://github.com/iandunn/audit-trail-extension/blob/master/audit-trail-extension.php#L112
	https://github.com/iandunn/audit-trail-extension/blob/master/audit-trail-extension.php#L133
	https://github.com/iandunn/audit-trail-extension/blob/master/audit-trail-extension.php#L139
	
there is usages of unserialize function		
```
					$option = unserialize( $item->data );
					$details = unserialize( $item->data );
```

without disallowing unneeded classes.
thus, if attacker managed to control the value of $item->data he will be able to:

1\. conduct PHP POP exploitation, more information:

http://www.slideshare.net/_s_n_t/php-unserialization-vulnerabilities-what-are-we-missing
http://www.slideshare.net/MailRuGroup/security-meetup-22-php-unserialize-exploiting

2\. unserialize itself has many security bugs in previous PHP versions which can be exploited, more information:

https://www.evonide.com/fuzzing-unserialize/
https://blog.checkpoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/Exploiting-PHP-7-unserialize-Report-160829.pdf

fix:

1\. don't use serialize/unserialize if json_encode/json_decode can be used instead. (fix both 1 & 2 attack vectors)
2\. if 1 isn't possible, use safe unserialize invocation, such as:
```
        if (version_compare(PHP_VERSION, '7.0', 'lt')) {
            return safeUnserialize($data);
        } else {
            return safeUnserialize($data, false);
        }
```

Implement safeUnserialize function that based on PMA_safeUnserialize:
https://github.com/phpmyadmin/phpmyadmin/blob/fb161a7bebe60d902f743227158eca6a9889c472/libraries/core.lib.php#L1080
but with fix for the issue described in:
https://hackerone.com/reports/181315#activity-1322058
vulnerability_information_html:
in:
https://github.com/iandunn/audit-trail-extension/blob/master/audit-trail-extension.php#L106
https://github.com/iandunn/audit-trail-extension/blob/master/audit-trail-extension.php#L112

https://github.com/iandunn/audit-trail-extension/blob/master/audit-trail-extension.php#L139

there is usages of unserialize function 

                    $option = unserialize( $item->data );
                    $details = unserialize( $item->data );

without disallowing unneeded classes.
thus, if attacker managed to control the value of $item->data he will be able to:

1. conduct PHP POP exploitation, more information:

http://www.slideshare.net/_s_n_t/php-unserialization-vulnerabilities-what-are-we-missing
http://www.slideshare.net/MailRuGroup/security-meetup-22-php-unserialize-exploiting

2. unserialize itself has many security bugs in previous PHP versions which can be exploited, more information:

https://www.evonide.com/fuzzing-unserialize/
https://blog.checkpoint.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/Exploiting-PHP-7-unserialize-Report-160829.pdf

fix:

1. don't use serialize/unserialize if json_encode/json_decode can be used instead. (fix both 1 & 2 attack vectors)
2. if 1 isn't possible, use safe unserialize invocation, such as:

        if (version_compare(PHP_VERSION, '7.0', 'lt')) {
            return safeUnserialize($data);
        } else {
            return safeUnserialize($data, false);
        }

Implement safeUnserialize function that based on PMA_safeUnserialize:
https://github.com/phpmyadmin/phpmyadmin/blob/fb161a7bebe60d902f743227158eca6a9889c472/libraries/core.lib.php#L1080
but with fix for the issue described in:
https://hackerone.com/reports/181315#activity-1322058

activities.message: Thanks Emanuel, this looks valid at first glance.
activities.markdown_message: Thanks Emanuel, this looks valid at first glance.

activities.message:
Actually, now that I think about it, that plugin only works if the Audit Trail plugin is running, and Audit Trail makes the decision to store `$item` in a serialized string.

So, this would need to be fixed in Audit Trail first, before anything could be done in `audit-trail-extension`.
activities.markdown_message:
Actually, now that I think about it, that plugin only works if the Audit Trail plugin is running, and Audit Trail makes the decision to store $item in a serialized string.

So, this would need to be fixed in Audit Trail first, before anything could be done in audit-trail-extension.

activities.message: Closing since this needs to be fixed upstream first.
activities.markdown_message: Closing since this needs to be fixed upstream first.

activities.message: in case upstream will not change the serialize call/format, you need to disallow not needed classes as I point in 2 in fix (under "use safe unserialize invocation")
activities.markdown_message: in case upstream will not change the serialize call/format, you need to disallow not needed classes as I point in 2 in fix (under "use safe unserialize invocation")

activities.message:
It doesn't look like PMA_safeUnserialize() supports whitelisting objects, so that would have to be added.

It still doesn't seem necessary, though, because I don't see any way an attacker could manipulate `$item`, unless they could already execute PHP code. There's no user input to take advantage of.

Here's where `$item` gets passed to my plugin by Audit Trail:

* https://plugins.trac.wordpress.org/browser/audit-trail/trunk/models/audit.php?rev=1167079#L197
* https://plugins.trac.wordpress.org/browser/audit-trail/trunk/models/audit.php?rev=1167079#L214

Can you demonstrate a way to pass a malicious object to my plugin?
activities.markdown_message:

It still doesn't seem necessary, though, because I don't see any way an attacker could manipulate $item, unless they could already execute PHP code. There's no user input to take advantage of.

Here's where $item gets passed to my plugin by Audit Trail:

  • https://plugins.trac.wordpress.org/browser/audit-trail/trunk/models/audit.php?rev=1167079#L197
  • https://plugins.trac.wordpress.org/browser/audit-trail/trunk/models/audit.php?rev=1167079#L214

Can you demonstrate a way to pass a malicious object to my plugin?

activities.message:
1\. one way is changing the value directly from the database (in case attacker managed to compromise the database / get access to it) then attacker will want to hack the client (execute PHP code), not sure how much a hardened wordpress installation (that use some of the following defines, so even admin can't run PHP code)
DISALLOW_FILE_EDIT
DISALLOW_FILE_MODS
is resistant to attack that come from compromised database, still it's better to not increase the attack surface.
2\. it might be possible to influence $item in creation time (will check if it's possible later), still it's better to protect from this (too not assume it be safe forever)

>It doesn't look like PMA_safeUnserialize() supports whitelisting objects, so that would have to be added.

yes, if support for PHP < 7 is needed (unserialize support whitelisted objects from PHP > 7)

activities.message: Doh, you're right, a compromised db is a practical vector.
activities.markdown_message: Doh, you're right, a compromised db is a practical vector.

activities.message: This is really old code that I doubt anybody is using, so I didn't bother doing a proper fix. I just [removed the serialization](https://github.com/iandunn/audit-trail-extension/commit/5076c714024167eef2c69d648b779110f2c92309) so that the raw string is displayed.
activities.markdown_message: This is really old code that I doubt anybody is using, so I didn't bother doing a proper fix. I just removed the serialization so that the raw string is displayed.
